word.entryDescription: something nice which is given to somebody who has been successful
word.entryExample: The first prize in the competition was a trip to London.

word.entryDescription: a way of doing something, especially the usual or correct way
word.entryExample: I was about to start the self-check-in procedure when I noticed a small grey rucksack on the floor next to the check-in machine.

word.entryDescription: (of food) with substances added to it before it is sold, in order to preserve it, improve its colour etc
word.entryExample: At our primary school the parents didn’t like the meals the children were being served for lunch, which included a lot of processed food.

word.entryDescription: making food, materials, or goods ready to be used or sold, for example by preserving or improving them in some way
word.entryExample: Changes in food packaging and processing mean that we now have loads of options when we go to the supermarket.

word.entryDescription: a part of a computer that controls all the other parts of the system
word.entryExample: The processor in my tablet is super-speedy.

word.entryDescription: to make, write etc something to be bought, used, or enjoyed by people
word.entryExample: Did you know that most of the chocolate we eat is produced in Africa?

word.entryDescription: a person, company or a country that grows or makes food, or makes other goods
word.entryExample: This country is the fifth largest producer of oil.

word.entryDescription: something you watch on television or listen to on the radio
word.entryExample: There's an interesting programme about sharks on TV.

word.entryDescription: a planned piece of work with a particular aim
word.entryExample: Mum, can you help me with my school project?

word.entryDescription: past simple of 'promise' – to say that something will definitely be done or happen
word.entryExample: She promised to be there on time so they could get to the match at 6:30.

word.entryDescription: to help sell a product, service, etc. or make it more popular by advertising it or offering it at a special price
word.entryExample: Persistent advertising campaigns on the television launch and promote products that nobody really needs – but are persuaded to want.

word.entryDescription: to make the sound of a letter, word etc, especially in the correct way
word.entryExample: These sounds are difficult to pronounce.

word.entryDescription: how individual sounds, and words, phrases and sentences are said
word.entryExample: I really want to learn Italian because I love the sound of it, the pronunciation is really musical.

word.entryDescription: land, a building, an office, an apartment, etc which belongs to a person or an organisation
word.entryExample: Right now you're on my farm and that can't be on your route because this is private property.

word.entryDescription: the most important character in a play, film, or story
word.entryExample: Protagonists of Greek tragedies have to deal with problems of destiny.

word.entryDescription: to keep something or someone safe from harm, damage, loss, etc
word.entryExample: If we change our attitude towards consumption we can protect the environment.

word.entryDescription: the state of protecting something
word.entryExample: Some conservation organisations work on habitat protection.

word.entryDescription: a substance found in meat, eggs, dairy products, nuts, etc which helps the body to grow and stay strong
word.entryExample: Meat is a good source of protein.

word.entryDescription: to express your disapproval of or opposition to something
word.entryExample: Many people blocked the street, protesting against the new law.

word.entryDescription: the first version of a new product
word.entryExample: So far, the architects have built a wooden prototype.

word.entryDescription: thinking that you are more important, skilful etc than you really are
word.entryExample: She look vain and proud.

word.entryDescription: feeling pleased about yourself and your achievements or about someone or something you are involved with or related to
word.entryExample: I am very proud of this class and their results.

word.entryDescription: to give evidence to show that something is true
word.entryExample: Well, that's a popular opinion, but there's no evidence to prove it.

word.entryDescription: to give something to somebody or make it available for them to use
word.entryExample: Full training and a uniform are provided.

word.entryDescription: the study of the mind and behaviour
word.entryExample: In psychology this is called 'enclothed cognition', which means clothes influence the wearer.

word.entryDescription: the stage during which children's bodies change into adult ones
word.entryExample: Puberty causes a very important change in our body and mind.

word.entryDescription: where other people can see you
word.entryExample: I took a deep breath, and faced my biggest fear: public performance.

word.entryDescription: (usually plural) a service, such as transport or health care, that a government provides
word.entryExample: A number of public services and voluntary bodies are engaged in fighting drug misuse at local level.

word.entryDescription: methods of travelling such as trains, buses, trams, etc which are available for everybody to use
word.entryExample: If you need to travel far or on a motorway, share a car with other people or use public transport.

word.entryDescription: a person or company that deals with producing books, magazines, etc
word.entryExample: Berry asked John Lennon to record three songs owned by his publisher.

word.entryDescription: a small pool of water on the ground, which often appears during rain
word.entryExample: Rain causes puddles on the ground.

word.entryDescription: to injure a muscle by stretching it too much during physical activity
word.entryExample: I have to be careful because I pulled a muscle playing football last month.

word.entryDescription: the soft part of a fruit – not the seeds
word.entryExample: Inside each cocoa fruit there are 30-50 seeds, surrounded by a sweet, tasty pulp which doesn't taste like chocolate at all.

word.entryDescription: past simple form of 'punctuate' – to interrupt something at intervals
word.entryExample: The peformance of the stand-up comedian was punctuated by bursts of laughter.

word.entryDescription: to make somebody suffer because they have broken the law or done something wrong
word.entryExample: Do you think criminals should always be punished for their crimes?

word.entryDescription: a person who likes punk music (a type of loud and aggressive rock music popular in the late 1970s and early 1980s) and dresses like a punk musician
word.entryExample: Steven used to be a punk in the1980s.

word.entryDescription: a child student
word.entryExample: Here's a photo of me with some of my primary school pupils.

word.entryDescription: a young dog
word.entryExample: I got my dog when he was a puppy.

word.entryDescription: something that is purple is the colour between red and blue
word.entryExample: My mum is wearing a purple hat.

word.entryDescription: a small bag most often used by a woman to keep her money
word.entryExample: I keep my money in a purse.

word.entryDescription: to move something away from you or to another position usually with your hands
word.entryExample: Push the bike up the hill.

word.entryDescription: to move something into a particular position
word.entryExample: Can you put the flowers into water, please?

word.entryDescription: to decide that something should happen later than previously arranged
word.entryExample: The match has been put off due to bad weather.

word.entryDescription: to cover a part of your body with a piece of clothing
word.entryExample: It's very windy, so put on your coat.

word.entryDescription: to become heavier or fatter
word.entryExample: Couch potatoes prefer playing video games to sports. They tend to put on weight.

word.entryDescription: to try to force or to persuade somebody to do something
word.entryExample: Nationally and internationally we put pressure on governments to cut their greenhouse gas emissions.

word.entryDescription: to connect somebody who is making a telephone call to somebody else
word.entryExample: If we can't answer your questions, we can put you through to someone who can.

word.entryDescription: to prepare something by collecting pieces of information, ideas etc
word.entryExample: Would you be able to help me put together a new CV?

word.entryDescription: to raise something to a higher position
word.entryExample: Put your hand up if you want to ask a question.

word.entryDescription: small pieces of wood in different shapes that you join together to make a picture
word.entryExample: Can you help me with this puzzle?
